awd_titl_txt: Genetic Encoding of Tetrazine Amino Acids to Develop Ideal Bioorthogonal Ligations
awd_abstract_narration:
Biological processes function through extremely complex interactions of macromolecules that take place over an enormous range of timescales and molecular specificity. Controlled modification of biomolecules enables scientists to explore living systems, engineer new biological functions and generate new biomaterials. Currently the speed and selectivity of the reactions that modify (label) proteins in living and non-living systems limit the ability to study protein dynamics, processing and interactions as well as to engineer novel protein function. Development of an ideal reaction for labeling proteins that is selective in biological conditions and is fast enough to compete with natural biological processes will overcome many of the current limitations. Amino acids are building blocks of proteins and they are inserted in a precisely defined sequence during protein synthesis. Thus, genetically encoding a modified amino acid that contains the needed labeling reaction components and is incorporated into a protein allows for site-specific modification of proteins and enables many new research avenues and potential biotechnological applications.  In this project, a modified amino acid carrying a tetrazine group (which meets the demands of an ideal labeling reaction) will be incorporated into proteins.  The speed and specificity of reaction of this tetrazine-protein in both living and non-living systems permits coupling with a variety of markers targeted for different selected functions. This platform for expansion of the genetic code will be incorporated into undergraduate courses as an approach to teaching chemical biology and to illustrate how engineering the chemical modification of biopolymers is both possible and critical for understanding and manipulating their function.  An annual workshop will be held for high school science teachers and researchers (undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate)  to learn genetic code expansion methodology. 

The ideal bioorthogonal ligation will be developed and key functional groups will be site-specifically incorporated into proteins via genetic code expansion. Tetrazine containing amino acids will be designed and synthesized to be highly reactive with strained trans-cyclooctene functionalities bearing labels, but selective unreactive with other cellular components. Tetrazine-amino acids will also be genetically incorporated into eukaryotes and prokaryotes and characterized. Tetrazine-protein stability and reaction rates will be measured for labeling and dimerizing proteins in vivo at sub-stoichiometric concentrations of label. This reaction has the potential to transform protein studies and protein engineering because it will be quantitative in vivo on biological time scales of seconds to minutes and at biological concentrations of tetrazine-protein and label. To demonstrate the utility of this bioorthogonal labeling reaction in vivo, key functions integral to two-component signaling systems will be switched on and off with precise control to understand their mechanism of regulating transcription.

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
Overall impact summary of prior award: MCB-1518265 (2015-2020): Genetic Encoding of Tetrazine Amino Acids to Develop Ideal Bioorthogonal Ligations, 07/01/15 – 08/30/19. The technology developed with this support resulted in 30 publications, 23 of which reference this award, two patents, two patent applications pending, and the licensing of tetrazine technology to a startup company for generating protein sensors. The support assisted in the training of 20 undergraduates, including one Goldwater scholar and one NSF fellow, and 75% of those eligible have proceeded to medical school or graduate school. The support has assisted in training my first six graduate students and the first three have successfully defended their theses and obtained positions in academia and industry. The publications from this period have resulted in authorship for 23 graduate students, 5 post-doctoral scholars and 6 undergraduates. This NSF award helped start the first formal Genetic Code Expansion (GCE) training program (annually 2015-2018) and conference (2016, 2018).  

Intellectual Merit: The previous NSF grant focused on advancing GCE technology, education and bioorthogonal labeling methods through publications and collaborations. The publications from the last funded work have been cited over 350 times to date. Our NSF-funded bioorthogonal technology has been well received and cited over 400 times in the last seven years.

The publications (23) supported by this award can be organized into the following four categories:

(1) Bioorthogonal ligations: (10 publications) These works showed it is possible to perform quantitative and sub-stochiometric bioorthogonal labeling in minutes in live E. coli and eukaryotic cells with tetrazine amino acids. These works also include the first genetic encoding of triazines and cyclopropenones, which expanded the options for orthogonal labeling. Tetrazine (Tet) labeling was applied to protein conformational changes via FRET, heteromeric motor protein assembly, and the first quantitative control of protein loading on surfaces.

(2) GCE education and dissemination: (4 publications) This includes GCE field reviews and GCE conference impacts. A major dissemination includes a 15-year project to develop a full semester, research-based laboratory course utilizing genetic code expansion for implementation in small and large courses.

(3) Improving core GCE translation: (3 publications) These publications describe advances in engineering core translation components to improve efficiency and fidelity of GCE.

(4) Integrating GCE into new fields: (6 publications) These include our efforts to broaden GCE impact by using GCE modified proteins in protein polymer hybrids, mechanistic enzymology, structural biology, and the first use of halogen bonds as a new approach for stabilizing protein structure.

Broader Impacts: Benefits to society that resulted from the previous funding include advances in undergraduate education, Unnatural Protein Facility service, and GCE workshops and conferences.

Undergraduate education: Previous funding from the NSF helped purchase additional bacterial shakers, which expanded our teaching capacity from 60 to 100 students per year and allowed for continued development of a full laboratory course that focuses on chemical biology and GCE. The course manual is also published to help others design similar courses using the technology: Unnatural Chemical Biology: Research-Based Laboratory Course Utilizing Genetic Code Expansion. J. Chem. Educ. 2019, 96(1), 66-74.

Unnatural Protein Facility:  In 2011, I started the first Unnatural Protein (UP) Facility at OSU and it is dedicated to assisting and training scientists in genetic code expansion technology. NSF support has ensured that the new ncAA tools are easy to implement in other research labs by allowing us to develop streamlined protocols and optimized expression systems.

GCE workshops and conferences: The UP Facility initiated annual weeklong training workshops to broaden the impact of GCE (2015-2018). These workshops have assisted over 80 researchers with their specific GCE problem and NSF funding was instrumental in providing stipends that allowed 26 women and underrepresented minority researchers to attend.  

 


Last Modified: 05/16/2022
Modified by: Ryan A Mehl
